Just a reminder, avoid those crummy homemade DVD sets of the MR cartoon on Ebay!
Monster Rancher Metropolis: The Cafe: Archived Topics From Prior Years: Year 2005 Topics (Year of the Mocchi Scream): Just a reminder, avoid those crummy homemade DVD sets of the MR cartoon on Ebay!
By Lisa Shock on Saturday, August 20, 2005 - 08:48 pm:

A real DVD box set of all 3 seasons (73 episodes) is coming this fall from Digiview Productions, who now owns the MR license along with a whole group of shows purchased from the bankruptcy of BKN.

I am seeing people on Ebay paying $60+ for each season of the show, for home-burned DVDs compiled off of VHS tapes taken off the air -lousy quality transfers on media that won't last more than a year! Don't throw your money away on this junk!

By Jovial_Evil on Monday, August 22, 2005 - 11:05 am:

That is great, Box sets usually have extras that you don't get w/ single volumes.

Overstock has the MR DVDs vol.1-4 for $15.26USD each.
here is a link.

By VenomousX on Monday, August 22, 2005 - 11:42 am:

Does Digiview Productions have a link where they plan to sell the 3 seasons?

By Nimrook on Monday, August 22, 2005 - 12:29 pm:

Um.. can I get them in UK?

By John Hawley on Monday, August 22, 2005 - 02:59 pm:

[quote] That is great, Box sets usually have extras that you don't get w/ single volumes.
[/quote]

Not for value boxsets. They generally have even less extras than the singles.

By Lisa Shock on Monday, August 22, 2005 - 03:22 pm:

Digiview makes those cheap DVDs you see of old 1950s tv shows and old B&W movies. They don't have any online ordering site that I have been able to find. I believe that they distribute in the PAL regions, but very little is known about this yet.

And, ya, don't expect extras or anything with these sets. Just be glad to finally get a look at season 3.

By Lisa Shock on Wednesday, August 24, 2005 - 12:17 pm:

And, while there may not be extras, at least the quality should be very good. The guy selling on ebay taped everything with his VCR, then transferred it to DVD. And, because it's on home-burned DVD, the disc may not last more than a year because it's not sealed like a professional DVD.
